newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil's left wing slams plan to sell CVRD.
newsitem.headline: Brazil's left wing slams plan to sell CVRD.

text.p: Brazil's left-wing political parties on Wednesday strongly criticized the upcoming privatization of Companhia Vale do Rio Doce (CVRD) and said they were close to calling a congressional probe into the mining conglomerate's sale.

"The model for the privatization of CVRD is under suspicion, and we need to hold a parliamentary commission of inquiry (CPI) to investigate," Deputy Jose Machado of the Workers Party said at an emotionally charged public hearing held in Congress.

Deputy Miro Texeira of Democratic Labor Party told the newswire Invest News that a petition calling for a parliamentary commission to investigate the CVRD privatization was just one signature short of the number required.
Senator Jose Eduardo Dutra, who is in charge of mustering signatures for the petition, earlier told Reuters the list was not complete but declined to give further details.
A congressional investigation could delay by months the government's plan to begin privatizating CVRD on April 29, when it is due to sell a block of 40 to 45 percent of the company's voting shares.

The privatization, which will also involve the sale of shares to CVRD employees and international investors, is set to become Latin America's largest, with revenues expected to total about $6.0 billion.

Left-wing lawmakers have accused U.S. investment bank Merrill Lynch & Co Inc of failing to declare what they consider to be a conflict of interest when the bank was appointed as an official consultant to the CVRD privatization.

The lawmakers say Merril Lynch's ownership of the South African brokerage Smith Borkham Hare represents a conflict of interest because that firm acts as sponsoring broker in Johannesburg to South Africa's Anglo American Corp, which is expected to bid in the April 29 auction for CVRD.
Merrill Lynch has denied the allegations.
Luiz Carlos Mendonca de Barros, the president of the National Development Bank (BNDES), which is in charge of Brazil's privatization program, also denied there had been any irregularity.
At the public hearing on Wednesday, he said Merrill Lynch bought the South African firm before the BNDES opened the bidding for the CVRD consultancy contract.
"People are trying to make a drama out of this," Mendonca de Barros said.
